thread.title: Smarter Teens Smoke More Pot | Men’s Health
thread.title_full: Smarter Teens Smoke More Pot | Men’s Health

title: Smarter Teens Smoke More Pot | Men’s Health
text:
Privacy Policy | About Us 
One substance they weren’t keen on experimenting with? Cigarettes. High-achieving kids in early adolescence—those from age 13 to 17—were significantly less likely to pick up the smokes than those who did worse in school. 
The increased chances of high-achieving kids drinking and smoking pot—but skipping on cigarettes—is consistent with that of adults, the researchers say. 
One possible reason may be because people with higher cognitive abilities may be more likely to have a personality that’s open to new experiences, they write. And that might encourage the high-achievers to experiment with marijuana and alcohol. (Here’s what you need to know if you’re traveling to smoke legal weed .) 
The experimentation might pose a problem, though—not only do the associations persist into adulthood, but the negative outcomes of smoking pot seem to be worse the earlier you start and the more you use it, study author James Williams told The Telegraph .
